issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity), but the example usage in Main.java and the reference solution’s SealSaloon.acceptSupplyDelivery take only three parameters (String ingredientName, int price, int quantity). This parameter count mismatch will confuse students about the correct method signature to implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Either update the problem statement and UML to specify acceptSupplyDelivery(String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) (dropping the unused supplierName), or adjust the solution and example code to include the supplierName parameter so all artifacts use the same four-parameter signature.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify acceptSupplyDelivery to take four parameters (String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity), but the solution’s SealSaloon.acceptSupplyDelivery method only takes three parameters (String name, int price, int quantity). This discrepancy in method signature and parameter naming creates confusion about how to handle the supplierName and ingredientName arguments.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the solution’s acceptSupplyDelivery signature to match the problem specification: public static void acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity), and adjust the implementation to handle both supplierName and ingredientName accordingly.
